top_categories.workout_context: Bootlegger 100's North Georgia mountains gravel (80%), Dirt roads (20%) forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 100 miles.
100ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Bootlegger 100's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before April.
At Bootlegger 100, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
At mile 60 of 100, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
10,000ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Bootlegger 100. Train it until it feels boring.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Bootlegger 100, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
10,000ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
Low-cadence force work for 10,000ft of climbing. The slow, grinding ascents where you can't spin—you push.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on north Georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 10,000ft of climbing on north Georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical does to your power file on race day.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Bootlegger 100’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Bootlegger 100 demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride north georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical descents at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: north georgia mountains gravel (80%), dirt roads (20%), steep appalachian climbs. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 100 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, TT Threshold, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 100 miles of north georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical descents in Dahlonega, Georgia (North Georgia mountains).
